questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the hospital because of blurred vision and headache for 3 months. During this period, the father noticed that the child has been tilting his head back to look straight ahead. The patient has also had difficulty falling asleep for 2 months. He has had a 3.5 kg (7.7 lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 104/62 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are not reactive to light. The pupils constrict when an object is brought near the eye. His upward gaze is impaired; there is bilateral nystagmus and eyelid retraction while attempting to look upwards. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. The remainder of the examination shows no other abnormalities. If left untreated, which of the following is the most likely sequela of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukocoria is a typical manifestation of retinoblastoma, which may cause nystagmus and loss of vision. However, the age of onset of retinoblastoma is typically < 4 years and this patient does not have strabismus, which is the most common initial manifestation. Parinaud syndrome and insomnia are not typical features of retinoblastoma. Moreover, leukocoria is a clinical finding and not a sequela of any medical condition.

Rarely, individuals with retinoblastoma may have an ectopic tumor in the pineal gland (i.e., trilateral retinoblastoma), causing Parinaud syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Pretibial myxedema is a sequela of Graves disease, which may manifest with weight loss, ocular symptoms (e.g., lid retraction), and insomnia. However, in contrast to this patient's ocular findings, Graves ophthalmopathy manifests with bilateral exophthalmos and conjunctival hyperemia, not with vertical gaze palsy. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as excessive sweating, tachycardia, and diffuse goiter.

C) INCORRECT:

Growth failure can result from compression of the pituitary gland due to intrasellar extension of a craniopharyngioma. Headaches, caused by compression of the adjacent brain parenchyma and/or stretching of the dura mater, and visual field defects (e.g., bilateral hemianopia), resulting from compression of the optic chiasm, are common in this condition. This patient most likely has a pinealoma, which can compress the hypothalamic inhibiting pathways and subsequently increase hCG secretion, leading to precocious puberty rather than growth failure.

D) CORRECT:

Parinaud syndrome occurs in most patients with pinealomas and is caused by compression of the tectum and the medial longitudinal fasciculus, which together coordinate eye movements. If left untreated, a pinealoma may obstruct the passage of cerebrospinal fluid from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space (e.g., via aqueductal stenosis) leading to obstructive hydrocephalus, a common sequela of pinealoma. Obstructive hydrocephalus typically manifests with headaches, vision abnormalities, nausea, vomiting, and impaired ambulation (e.g, ataxia) due to increased intracranial pressure.

The most common type of pinealoma in children is a pineal germinoma that typically secretes β-hCG, eventually leading to precocious puberty.

E) INCORRECT:

Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (OMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome that may develop in individuals with neuroblastoma. While weight loss and ocular anomalies (e.g., proptosis) may be present in individuals with neuroblastoma, it does not cause vertical gaze palsy, nystagmus, or Collier sign. Also, this patient has no features suggesting neuroblastoma, such as abdominal distension, bone pain, and a palpable, firm, irregular abdominal mass that crosses the midline.
questions.hint: This patient has vertical gaze palsy, nystagmus, eyelid retraction on looking upward (Collier sign), and pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, which suggests Parinaud syndrome. Additional symptoms of weight loss, headache, and insomnia raise suspicion for pinealoma.

questions.text: A previously healthy 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of increasing visual loss and deterioration of his hearing and speech over the past 2 months. During this period, he has had difficulty walking, using the stairs, and feeding himself. His mother reports that he has been unusually tired and has had frequent nausea. His teachers have noticed that he has had difficulty concentrating. His grades have worsened and his handwriting has become illegible. His maternal male cousin had similar symptoms and died at the age of 6 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows hyperpigmented skin and nails and an ataxic gait. His speech is dysarthric. Neurologic examination shows spasticity and decreased muscle strength in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response bilaterally. Sensation is decreased in the lower extremities. Fundoscopy shows optic atrophy. There is sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gaucher disease is the most common sphingolipidosis and results from a deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase. Typical symptoms include pancytopenia, bone pain, and hepatosplenomegaly. Neurodegeneration with ataxia, spastic tetraplegia, and progressive sensory loss are not seen in Gaucher disease.

B) CORRECT:

Adrenoleukodystrophy is a rare X-linked recessive neurological disease caused by a dysfunctional peroxisomal ATP-binding cassette transporter protein due to a mutation in the ABCD1 gene. This mutation leads to an accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids in the serum as well as the adrenal glands, testes, and white matter, and subsequent neuron demyelination. Adrenoleukodystrophy can sometimes manifest very similarly to other rare neurological conditions of childhood (e.g., sphingolipidoses, mucopolysaccharidoses). Often, the main distinguishing factor is the presence of adrenal insufficiency (usually manifesting with hyperpigmented skin but also fatigue, nausea, vomiting, hypotension, etc.). Adrenoleukodystrophy is primarily diagnosed via a very long-chain fatty acid panel or mutation analysis.

Treatment is primarily aimed at addressing adrenal insufficiency, if present, with steroids. However, this does not change the progressive neurologic dysfunction and most children die within 10 years following the diagnosis. For patients early in the course of their disease, allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can also be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Sphingomyelinase deficiency is the cause of Niemann-Pick disease, a lysosomal storage disease that leads to neurodegeneration, cherry-red spots on the macula, and hepatosplenomegaly in patients before the age of 1 year. Though this patient's motor symptoms and cognitive impairment are similar to those seen in Niemann-Pick disease, his age at presentation and the absence of hepatosplenomegaly and cherry-red spots make this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-hexosaminidase A deficiency leads to Tay-Sachs disease, a rare neurological disorder that causes progressive neurodegeneration in children. Although Tay-Sachs disease can cause progressive impairment of vision, hearing, cognition, and motor skills, the age of onset is much earlier compared to that of adrenoleukodystrophy (6 months versus 4–8 years), and it would not explain this patient's hyperpigmentation. Additionally, cherry-red spots on the macula are usually seen in Tay-Sachs disease, and their absence in this patient makes this an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency causes Fabry disease, which characteristically leads to severe distal limb pain and angiokeratomas beginning around the age of 10–17 years. Renal failure and cardiovascular disease occur in most patients between the ages of 30 and 40 years. Eye examination reveals characteristic corneal clouding or cataracts, not optic nerve atrophy. Additionally, Fabry disease would not explain this patient's progressive cognitive impairment, sensory loss, ataxia, hypotonia, or pigmented skin, making it an unlikely cause of his symptoms.
questions.hint: Rapidly deteriorating vision, hearing, motor abilities, and cognition alongside spastic tetraplegia, sensory loss, and adrenal insufficiency (suggested by hyperpigmented skin, fatigue, nausea) in a young boy are characteristic of adrenoleukodystrophy. A family history of what was likely the same condition in a maternal relative supports the diagnosis of this X-linked recessive disorder.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of irritability and frequent bed wetting. She also reports that he has been unable to look upward without tilting his head back for the past 2 months. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmological examination shows dilated pupils that are not reactive to light and bilateral optic disc swelling. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 2. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a tumor in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas often arise in the cerebral falx and are typically asymptomatic due to their slow growth rate. Compression of the adjacent hemisphere can cause seizures as well as spastic paraparesis and incontinence. Falcine meningiomas do not typically cause hydrocephalus or precocious puberty.

B) CORRECT:

Pinealoma is a childhood tumor of the dorsal midbrain that compresses the pretectal region, resulting in vertical gaze palsy. Because of the close proximity to the cerebral aqueduct, hydrocephalus (due to obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid outflow pathway) can also develop, which would explain this patient's increased intracranial pressure. The most common type of pinealoma in children is germinoma, which often secretes β-hCG, stimulating testosterone production and causing precocious puberty in boys.

Other causes of vertical gaze palsy include stroke, multiple sclerosis, and encephalitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Acoustic schwannoma is the most common tumor of the cerebellopontine angle. Compression of structures adjacent to the cerebellopontine angle can cause hydrocephalus, but the absence of vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) involvement (causes unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus, unsteady gait) in this patient and the relatively short clinical course (4 weeks) make acoustic schwannoma (a slow-growing tumor) an unlikely etiology. Furthermore, the median age of patients presenting with acoustic schwannoma is ∼ 50 years.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

D) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas are childhood tumors that are typically located in the fourth ventricle. This tumor most commonly presents with noncommunicating hydrocephalus, which can result in compression of a number of CNS structures and cause vertical gaze palsy and central precocious puberty. However, in the case of hydrocephalus due to an ependymoma, symptoms of hydrocephalus (e.g., irritability, urinary incontinence) would precede the onset of vertical gaze palsy unlike this patient who had a vertical gaze palsy before the onset of hydrocephalus symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Pituitary tumors arise within the sella turcica. These tumors can cause compression of the optic chiasm and manifest with bitemporal hemianopsia. Because the pituitary gland is not in close proximity to the ventricular system, hydrocephalus does not occur. In addition, pituitary tumors originating from gonadotropic cells (gonadotroph adenoma) are typically nonsecretory (inactive), resulting in hypogonadism due to the destruction of functioning gonadotropic cells, instead of precocious puberty.

F) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytoma and medulloblastoma are childhood tumors located in the cerebellar vermis. Hydrocephalus due to compression of the fourth ventricle by these tumors can cause vertical gaze palsy and central precocious puberty. However, in the case of hydrocephalus due to either of these tumors, symptoms of hydrocephalus (e.g., irritability, urinary incontinence) would precede the onset of vertical gaze palsy unlike this patient who had a vertical gaze palsy before the onset of hydrocephalus symptoms. Additionally, compression of the cerebellar vermis would cause truncal ataxia, which is not reported in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with vertical gaze palsy and signs of increased intracranial pressure (papilledema). These findings are suggestive of a brain tumor that is causing compression symptoms due to hydrocephalus. Signs of precocious puberty are due to the tumor cell line.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of decreased vision, hearing, and speaking over the past 3 months. During this time, he has also had difficulty walking, concentrating, drawing, and feeding himself. His maternal male cousin had similar complaints and died at the age of 5 years. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented mucosa and skin. His speech is dysarthric. Neurologic examination shows an ataxic gait, spasticity, and decreased muscle strength in all extremities. Fundoscopy shows optic atrophy. Serum studies show elevated concentrations of fatty acids with 22 or more carbons. A deficiency in which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lysosomal galactocerebrosidase deficiency causes Krabbe disease, a neurologic disease characterized by developmental delay, hypertonia, and visual impairment. This patient's history of motor dysfunction and vision loss (due to optic nerve atrophy) is similar to the characteristic symptoms of Krabbe disease. However, one hallmark of this disease is developmental delay starting before the age of 1 year, so this patient's normal development until the age of 8 years makes Krabbe disease unlikely. Neither elevated serum levels of VLCFAs nor hyperpigmented skin and mucosa would be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Adrenoleukodystrophy is a rare X-linked neurological disease caused by an impaired peroxisomal ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter protein due to a mutation in the ABCD1 gene. This mutation leads to an accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids in the serum as well as the adrenal glands, testes, and white matter, and subsequent neuron demyelination. Adrenoleukodystrophy can sometimes present very similarly to other rare neurologic conditions of childhood (e.g., sphingolipidoses, mucopolysaccharidoses). Often, the main distinguishing factor is the presence of adrenal insufficiency (usually hyperpigmented skin, but also nausea, vomiting, hypotension, etc.). It is primarily diagnosed via a very long-chain fatty acid panel or mutation analysis.

Treatment is primarily aimed at addressing adrenal insufficiency, if present, with steroids. However, this does not change the progressive neurologic dysfunction and most children die within 10 years following the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Arylsulfatase A deficiency causes metachromatic leukodystrophy, a lysosomal storage disease that can also lead to cognitive decline, optic nerve atrophy, and ataxia. Typically, it presents in children much younger than this patient (1–2 years), although a juvenile-onset variant exists. However, this diagnosis would not explain this patient's hyperpigmentation or elevated serum levels of VLCFAs.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitochondrial trifunctional protein deficiency is an autosomal recessive disease that causes impaired fatty acid oxidation. Characteristic symptoms include cardiomyopathy, myopathy, rhabdomyolysis, and hypoketotic hypoglycemia induced by fasting. Although this condition can manifest with peripheral neuropathy and pigmentary retinopathy, it would not explain this patient's optic atrophy, ataxia, dysarthria, or hyperpigmented skin and mucosa. In addition, because the mitochondria are not responsible for beta-oxidation of VLCFAs, an increase in serum levels would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Sphingomyelinase deficiency is the cause of Niemann-Pick disease, a lysosomal storage disease that leads to neurodegeneration, cherry-red spots on the macula, and hepatosplenomegaly in patients before the age of 1 year. Though this patient's motor symptoms and cognitive impairment are similar to those seen in Niemann-Pick disease, his age at presentation and the absence of hepatosplenomegaly and cherry-red spots make this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, Niemann-Pick disease would not explain this patient's elevated serum levels of VLCFAs.
questions.hint: Rapidly deteriorating vision, hearing, motor abilities, and cognition in the presence of spasticity, sensory loss, and adrenal insufficiency (suggested by hyperpigmented skin and mucosa) in a young boy with elevated serum levels of VLCFAs (i.e., fatty acids with ≥ 22 carbons) indicates adrenoleukodystrophy. A family history of a maternal relative with what was likely the same condition supports the diagnosis of this X-linked recessive condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of abnormal behavior for the past 3 weeks. The symptoms started after he was released from the hospital, where he was treated for herpes simplex encephalitis. His wife says that he has been eating increasing volumes of food and recently started putting nonfood items in his mouth and licking objects in the house. When they are home he often rubs his genitals on furniture, and he has also begun touching his genitals and masturbating in public. The patient appears docile. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 132 kg (291 lbs); BMI is 38 kg/m2. He is oriented to person but not to time or place. Neurological examination shows the ability to follow motor commands but an inability to name objects. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Damage to the subthalamic nuclei would not cause the disinhibited behavior (i.e., hyperorality, hyperphagia, hypersexuality) and visual agnosia seen here. The subthalamic nucleus is part of the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia; activation of the subthalamic nuclei decreases motor activity. Lesions to the subthalamic nucleus characteristically result in contralateral hemiballismus, which this patient does not have.

B) CORRECT:

Bilateral damage of the medial parts of the anterior temporal lobe (including the amygdalae) results in Kluver-Bucy syndrome (KBS). HSV-1 encephalitis is the most common cause of KBS as the virus shows neurotropism with a predilection for the medial temporal lobe. Symptoms of KBS include hyperorality, hyperphagia, docility, cognitive dysfunction, and visual agnosia. MRI is the most sensitive modality, particularly in the early stages of disease, and would show bilateral hyperintense temporal lobe lesions. Other causes of KBS include head trauma, stroke, malignancy, and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer, Pick, Parkinson, and Huntington disease).

If active HSV infection is suspected, treatment is with IV acyclovir; otherwise, therapy with psychotropic medications is recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Damage to the hippocampi would not cause the disinhibited behavior (i.e., hyperorality, hyperphagia, hypersexuality) and visual agnosia seen here. Bilateral hippocampal lesions would result in anterograde amnesia, which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Frontal lobe lesions are typically associated with disinhibited behavior (e.g., sexual behavior) and deficits in judgment, as seen here. However, this patient's hyperorality, visual agnosia, and hyperphagia would not be consistent with a frontal lobe lesion. Frontal lobe lesions may also be associated with the reemergence of primitive reflexes, Broca aphasia (dominant inferior frontal gyrus), urinary incontinence (frontal micturition center), deficits in conjugate horizontal gaze (frontal eye fields), and frontal gait disorder, which are also not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Damage to the mammillary bodies would be more likely to manifest with confusion, disorientation, indifference, and inattentiveness than hyperphagia, hyperorality, and hypersexuality. Moreover, damage to the mammillary bodies is also associated with ataxia and ophthalmoplegia (i.e., Wernicke encephalopathy) with or without amnesia (anterograde > retrograde) and confabulation (i.e., Korsakoff syndrome), which this patient does not have. Furthermore, damage to the mammillary bodies is commonly associated with thiamine (B1) deficiency secondary to chronic heavy alcohol use, which is not consistent with this patient's history.
questions.hint: New onset of disinhibited behavior (i.e., hyperorality, hyperphagia, hypersexuality) and visual agnosia in an individual with a recent history of HSV-1 encephalitis raises suspicion for Kluver-Bucy syndrome.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug use and hypertension is found unresponsive by a friend at home. When emergency medical personnel arrive, he is in a state of pulseless electrical activity, and they perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation for 45 minutes, until spontaneous circulation resumes.
Upon arrival to the emergency department, the patient is unresponsive to external stimuli. Targeted temperature management is initiated, the patient is intubated, and a sedative and neuromuscular blocking agent are started intravenously. The patient is afebrile with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 98/65 mm Hg.
CT of the head, performed on arrival, shows no acute abnormalities. Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
14.4
13.5–17.5


Sodium (mEq/liter)
138
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.7
3.5–5.0


Glucose (mg/dL)
111
70–100


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
34
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.4
0.8–1.3


An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm without ischemic changes.
The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit where targeted temperature management is maintained for 24 hours, after which the patient is rewarmed and weaned off all sedation. Forty-eight hours later, he remains comatose. His pupils are 4 mm in size and reactive bilaterally, and corneal reflexes are present; cough reflex is absent. The patient demonstrates repetitive, synchronous, bilateral facial, arm, truncal, and leg jerks, both with tactile stimulation and spontaneously. He flexes his upper extremities to painful response (decorticate posturing). An electroencephalogram shows a burst suppression pattern with no seizures. He has developed hypotension and requires low-dose norepinephrine to maintain his blood pressure.
Which one of the following findings in this patient most strongly portends a poor neurologic outcome?

choices.text: Myoclonus with a burst suppression pattern on electroencephalography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypotension, if severe enough, could theoretically cause cerebral hypoperfusion but has not been formally studied as an outcome predictor after cardiac arrest.

B) INCORRECT:

Although absent corneal and pupillary reflexes have been associated with poor prognosis after cardiac arrest, absent cough reflex has not.

C) INCORRECT:

Decorticate posturing has not been found to be associated with poor prognosis after cardiac arrest.

D) CORRECT:

Patients who suffer cardiac arrest have varying outcomes depending on the extent of their brain injury. Prognosis after cardiac arrest is important given the resources needed to sustain life and the difficulty that families face making decisions about treatment options for their loved ones. The neurologic examination can be used to help guide prognostication. The presence of any of the following neurologic deficits 24 hours after cardiac arrest can predict a poor prognosis with relatively high specificity: absent pupillary response, absent corneal reflex, and absent motor response to pain (the last of which is even more predictive at 72 hours).

Myoclonus is common after an anoxic brain injury. Some studies suggest that bilateral, diffuse myoclonus with synchronized movements may be associated with poor outcomes, especially if it occurs within the first 24 hours, but several recent, small studies suggest otherwise. There is stronger evidence to support an association between myoclonus and poor outcomes when the myoclonus is associated with a burst suppression pattern on electroencephalography (EEG). Other EEG patterns that are associated with a poor prognosis include status epilepticus (with or without myoclonic discharges) and complete suppression. Because status epilepticus can occur with or without muscle movement, most experts advise performing EEG in all patients who do not awaken after anoxic brain injury; EEG is performed continuously at some centers, but this might not be feasible at all centers.

In this particular case, the patient has intact pupillary, corneal, and motor responses at 24 hours, but he also has postanoxic myoclonus with bilateral, diffuse, synchronized movements and a burst suppression pattern on electroencephalography, which may portend a poor prognosis. Ultimately, prognostication after cardiac arrest requires a multifaceted approach, including clinical analysis, neurologic examination, and neurophysiological and neuroimaging studies.

Key learning point: In the first period after cardiac arrest, the most sensitive markers of poor outcome are lack of pupillary or corneal response, absence of motor response to pain, and a burst suppression pattern on electroencephalogram, all in the absence of sedation.

E) INCORRECT:

Unresponsiveness in the first few days after cardiac arrest is generally not a helpful predictor of long-term outcomes. Patients often require intubation and sedation after cardiac arrest and, as a result, are poorly responsive to commands on examination. In addition, medications may be cleared more slowly than normal if there is concurrent renal and hepatic insufficiency.
